response.answer_text: Let me put in a very simple manner. What is IP address? (Laying off the technical definition...)- When you connect your computer to any network , your computer is assigned (automatically or manually by user) an IP address. Consider this analogy. You have parked your car in a parking lot. When you want to go back to your car , you need to remember where you parked it. Suppose you remember this , 'beside the elevators in the third row'. When you have parked your car in a parking lot , you have assigned an address to it. Anyone wants to reach your car-machine , one can go to the parking lot -your network and check for the address-ip address assigned to it. When you connect to the internet , generally you are connecting your machine to the network provided by your Internet Service Provider.  Ok. Knowledge of Public IP Address is also required. Here it is. Just as no two parking spot have same address , IP address on a network is unique. Internet is ultimately just a network.( a huge network). So , if your machine has some IP address while accessing internet, no other machine in the entire world (accessing internet at the same time) can have that same IP address. This is called Public IP Address. It is provided by your ISP.  How does your ISP get these Public IPs?ISP buys Public IP addresses in bulk.  Ideally , ISP having 50k customers should have 50k Public IP Addresses. But not all the customers are connected to internet all the time. So, to utilize it's investment , ISP buys less public IP addresses than customers. Say , 40k IP Addresses for 50k customers. (Another analogy if you didn't quite catch that. Consider a car rental company. If 10 customers come everyday to rent cars , company should own 10 cars. But life is uncertain , and customers are not all coming at the same time. And company comes to know that on an average , 3 cars are always in the lot , unused. So , to utilize its investment , company only buys 7 cars.)Now , one Public IP can't be assigned to each customer as there are 40k IP addresses and 50k customers. So , what ISP does is , whenever you connect to internet , it randomly assigns you one of the public IP addresses. Now when you connect to the internet the next time , it is possible that the previous Public IP address is now assigned to someone else and you are assigned some other Public IP address.(One day you go to car rental company and rent a black Honda Civic for a day. You go the next day and you may get a red Honda Civic because black is already taken by another customer. ) Simple as that. ;)

If you’re using consumer-grade internet service, then the IP address assigned to your house network (i.e. the IP address used to communicate with the public internet by the cable modem and/or router that your ISP provides) is selected randomly from a pool of IP addresses that was allocated to your ISP. It can change; you explicitly have no guarantee it will remain the same. It’s only assigned to your router temporarily (“leased”, in networking terms; other keywords here are “DHCP” where the “D” stands for “dynamic”, which is computer speak for “it changes”). Despite the no-guarantees-may-change-at-any-time aspect, often your dynamically allocated IP address will, in fact, stay the same for weeks or months at a time. You can pay extra for a “static IP”, but it usually costs more. The main reason you’d need a static IP is to make something on your network (e.g. a web server) consistently available to the outside world. This usually costs extra. Also, most everything about how your ISP’s network is set up assumes the connections are all going to be initiated outward-bound, so there may be issues with firewall and router configuration in your ISP’s network infrastructure that they need to deal with to make your static IP available to the outside Internet.. There are “dynamic DNS” services (like dyndns.org, and others) that will make it easier to keep track of your router’s external IP address. In a nutshell, they’re like regular DNS — i.e. you reserve a domain name and the service hosts an entry that keeps track of what IP address goes with that domain name — except that it’s set up to make it easier to deal with a frequently -changing IP address. To use a dynamic DNS provider, you run a piece of software on your computer or router (many home/small office routers now come with support for this built in). This software will automatically contact the dynamic DNS server and update their DNS record for your domain, whenever your ISP’s DHCP assigns a new/different IP address to your router. The dynamic DNS server configures your DNS entry with a very low TTL (“Time To Live”) so that anyone who requests the details for your domain name will only cache it for a very short period of time. When your IP address changes and you update the dynamic DNS server, you won’t have to wait hours or even days for the cached DNS records to expire. DHCP is also often used inside your home network (almost always, for consumer grade home or small office networks). Most consumer grade routers these days are in fact combo devices including router, firewall, DHCP server and wifi AP (and usually a 4-port switch). When you plug in a new computer, the computer broadcasts a DHCP request asking for an IP address, and your router’s built-in DHCP server hears it and responds. The built-in DHCP server keeps track of which IP addresses have been assigned and which are still available for new devices. Network cards have a built-in identifier called a MAC address, and most consumer router/etc combos these days will remember which IP address was handed out to which MAC address, and re-issue that same IP address to the same MAC address when the DHCP “lease” expires. That’s not formally a part of the DHCP standard, but it simplifies life a lot.

This is a complex question and depends on the context. I will now generalize some things. If you surf on the Internet and visit for example http://quora.com this service has IP-address which serves the quora website. This IP-address does not change. DNS (domain name system) maps the quora.com name to the to specific IP-address. These server IP-addresses do not basically change.  Each device that is connected to global Internet needs IP-address in order to send and receive data from Internet. So let's take for an example your mobile device. If you are surfing at home using WiFi, now your own Public IP-address is depended on your ISP (Internet service provider). If you disconnect your device from WiFi and use cellural data your Public IP-address changes to your cellural data providers IP address. ISP usually sends IP-address to you using DHCP-protocol. DHCP-protocol has leases for each IP-address they provide. Usually if you are using WiFi-router at home your Public IP-address does not change as the router acquires the same IP-address over and over again. But if you disconnect your router for a week and then connect that back your IP-address may have changed as your lease is expired and DHCP-server have assigned your IP-address to another user. IP-address space (for IPv4) is 0.0.0.0 - 255.255.255.255 these addresses can't change. So you can't have for example IP-address 300.1.1.1 ever. So on this context the IP-addresses don't change.  To summarize: - IPv4 address space is static and all devices have some IP-address between earlier mentioned address space. - Servers usually have static IP-addresses and these addresses do not change. (Very generalized) - Your own device IP-address changes based on the location on which your are using it.

Most of the time, yes. Some of the time, No. And occasionally, maybe. I understand if that’s a confusing answer. The reason for it is there are multiple ways IP addresses can be configured. Most of us have a Dynamic IP address. With one of these, your device connecting to the network or internet is assigned an IP address that is good for X amount of time (think hours or days). At the end of this time, if it’s in use, it will renew it’s assignment (most of the time) and you will continue with that same IP address. If it’s not in use when it’s assigned time (it’s lease) is over, then the IP address becomes available for another device to use, and when you reconnect you get a new IP address. Some connections will be configured for a Static IP address instead of a Dynamic one. With this, instead of your device asking “what IP address can I have?” it’s going “Hey, this is my IP address”. Your device has a fixed IP address that your network provider (ISP) has set aside for you, so it never expires (well, as long as you keep paying the bill it won’t expire). Servers (webservers, email, file servers, domain controllers, etc) are likely to have a Static IP because your server address changing is a Bad Thing. So why aren’t all IP addresses static? Because there aren’t enough. The theoretical number of IPv4 addresses is a bit over 4.2 billion (the real number of possibly usable addresses is less then that). That may seem like a lot, but remember, there are 7+ billion people alive right now. While IPv6 addresses this limit, it’s adoption is far from universal so far. Ok, so what about that “Maybe” answer? Some ISPs (Internet Service Providers) and Networks use a 3rd category of IP addresses. These are basically dynamic IP addresses that are tied to a devices hardware address (it’s MAC). They act like some weird combination of Dynamic and Static IPs. They are assigned like Dynamic IPs, but like Static IPs they don’t actually change (unless someone at the network makes a mistake… which does happen). I want to say this type of IP address is going away, but I’ve seen it in place just a couple weeks ago.

IP Addresses don't change, per say. They are re-assigned.  There are two methods of assigning IP addresses in your typical network - Static, and Dynamic.  Think of it as visiting a hotel - each time you go back you are unlikely to get the same room (IP Address). This would be a dynamic IP address.  Now, if you change to a house, you are guaranteed to get the same room/address each time you go back until a change is made. This would be a static IP address.  This, in very basic terms, is the difference between dynamic and static IP's.  It sounds like your question refers to dynamic IP addresses. If you take your laptop to a cafe and check your IP address, it could be (for example) 10.1.10.6. If you leave and come back the next week, it could be 10.1.10.104. When you left, the assignment to your computer expired on the router, which freed up the IP address to be re-assigned to another customer. When you came back, your computer requests a new IP address, and the router pulls one from its inventory to assign (if one is available).  Hopefully this makes sense and helps clear things up. It's more complicated than this in reality, but I tried to break it down and keep things simple.

Yes and No. So ill try to make this as simple as I can, IP addresses IPV4 that everyone knows (192,168.10.1) for example are ment for network to network communication. But there is also an IPV6 address (2001:DBA;ACAD:B::1/64) for example. These can both be assigned Statically or Dynamically: Static meaning: Pretty much a set in stone address for that end device (Mainly used for most often printers, or desktops that are used often) ((Mainly used in small networks like 200 or less devices)) Dynamic meaning: Its on a “lease” where the device will send out a request for an address to the DHCP server. The server will acknowledge this, say I have this pool to choose from. Assign the device the address from say (2pm - 10 pm) after this the device will forfeit its address cutting off its access. (( Used in large or Enterprise networks, 200 - 1000+ devices.)) Reason behind this, this will help reduce the routers ARP table, so the router doesn't take up to much memory thus reducing the QOS of the routing process. This is pretty much best of my knowledge so if anyone see’s anything incorrect. Feel free to correct me.

For home users generally yes. When a new device attaches to the Internet via your home modem or router a protocol call Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP)[1] is used to assign an IP address to the device. This assignment has a lease period after which a new assignment will take place. In addition to an IP address, DHCP can also provide other configuration details such as default gateway, domain name, the name servers, and time servers. Servers usually have a fixed IP address (or are at least fronted by a router with a fixed IP address) as the Domain Name System (DNS)[2] converts a name to a fixed IP address. Sometimes your home device might need a fixed IP address, for example as a security precaution when a server only allows access from specific IP addresses. In this case you would need to obtain a fixed IP address from your ISP, usually as a paid additional service. Footnotes[1] Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol - Wikipedia[2] Domain Name System - Wikipedia

Imagine you walk into a bank operating on a token based system. On a certain day you'd get a token with number 9. On anohter day it would be token number 127(networking enthusiasts would love this token :P). One some fine day it can be Token number 192(this too xD). And who knows, on few days you might not even be able to go inside because it's too damn full! The idea here is that, the bank is the network. The token number is just a method to address you. And hence it's synonmous to the IP address. You might not get the same token, the next time. Depending on the crowd you'd get a particular number. Simlarly, depending on the network you're accessing, a particular number (or address) might be assigned to you. Therefore as such, your IP seems to "change".

The address itself doesn't change, but the physical device it's assigned to or being used by can change.  The network it's a part of can be routed differently, ie to another location or organization, or not routed at all.  How it's treated by various networks and remote servers can change, for example if it had been used by an abusive host (spamming, virus, etc) in the past someone with that IP (even a different host) might be blocked because of the past behavior.  The organization it's assigned by the Regional Internet registry might change. The address itself is just a number, so it doesn't change.  In fact, that's a large part of why we have the concept of layer 3 (OSI model) addresses.  The underlying physical address can change without the rest of the Internet having to know about it.

Mostly people still talk about IPV4 when they talk about IPs. They are still the most sought after because they are routed in more places. IPs are assigned to Networks who get them by showing they can use them properly.  Many hosting companies host 1,000's of websites on a single IP! Big websites like to have thier own ip's, called a STATIC ip, because it usually ranks better in search engines - often because you can have a static reverse DNS entry. Servers need an IP of their own. On your computers at home you use internal IPs which keeps them more secure and are dynamically assigned. DHCP dynamically assigns IPs - that means that if you unplug your computer you might be assigned a different IP. You can force a release of an IP from your computer by going into command prompt on your comoputer and typing ipconfig /release. When a network is sold sometimes the IPs go to the new company. On a network each computer is identified also by a MAC address. These don't change- not unless they are masked or spoofed.

In general, every router or device has its own IP allocated to that specific device. It stays there. But it ca change. Your ISP is responsible for distributing and maintaining a block of dynamic IP addresses that are continually circulated throughout their customer base. It stands to reason, therefore, that if you move house and change broadband providers, your IP address will also change. You can also change your IP when you connect to other IP addresses. This is usually done through proxy services or VPN. Since these services are usually used to avoid geo-restrictions or change your location, it also changes your IP address. This can be used for privacy reasons as well as for work-related matters or to access content that isn’t available in your country/region.

Yes and No. A user IP, like a broadband connection to you telco would change, according to the telco's dynamic IP policy. It might expire in an hour, a day or a few days. Telcos refresh their IP assignment to keep enough dynamic IPs to be allocated to clients so that they can access the Internet. Home Internet often falls into the same category. As for IP address assigned to or leased by corporations to attach their webserver, or any kind of digital service where IP address consistency is required, these would remain fixed to a specific machine, usually a corporate firewall. This type of IP address are leased from authorized bodies that handle a specific IP block, based on a geopolitical regions.

Further to the answers below, if you, your ISP or the country authority has allocated IPv4 ranges that are not fully utilized, then you may be requested to either defend keeping that range and/or to accept a change to a smaller range that better reflects your current usage. Server addresses are allocated out of the pool/s that the service provider has allocated to them - you don’t “own” the IP address, it is just loaned to you whilst you keep paying your bills and utilize their infrastructure in the same way. If you moved your server to a different site, even with the same service provider, you will be allocated a different IPv$ # - the old number typically stays routed to the same physical site and isn’t migrated. Even “fixed” IP home/office Internet connections are not guaranteed to never change, just not change just due to time or reconnection. If we where being REALLY pedantic, you can say the address doesn’t change, just the device it is allocated to may. (And generally not a good idea(tm) if two devices claim the same address)

If you renew your IP address from your current ISP, your ISP may or may not assign you a new IP address. Depending on how you're connected to the Internet, you may have to reset different device. If you're connected via a router, you'll have to change IP address of your router. If you're connected directly to the Internet via a layer-2 gateway, you'll have to change your computer's IP address. Most home network is connected via a router, so chances are that you need to change IP address of your router. In this article, I will describe how to change IP address of your router and also show you how to change IP address of your computer. There are a number of ways to change IP address, so I'll describe easiest method first and then describe a bit more complicated methods.

Only with the cooperation of whoever assigned it originally. In most cases, using an IP address on any Internet facing equipment that was not assigned by your ISP will cause problems and be a violation of some contract with the ISP. If the device in question is on a local LAN, then you can change it as you wish. Using an IP address not intended to be used in such a scenario will probably make something stop working, but it will likely be restricted to your LAN. If you don’t know when you can make a change or don’t know what or how to to change, then your best bet is to not do it.

IP addresses usually come in two types 1 Static2 Dynamic  Static IP address as the name suggests do not change they remain same , they are usually used by web servers and other devices that need to be there when a particular address is typed. Dynamic IP address are those IP addresses that change whenever the router is restarted these are usually used for broadband at home where internet is used just to browse the internetHope this helped you !

It depends on your provider. With some it might be as simple as rebooting your router although many ISPs have long leases now. You may also be able to get a static IP from them which might be easier to change.

Sure. The easiest way would likely be to change the MAC address on your router’s WAN-facing port and reconnected/power-cycle the device. This works because your old IP address is associated with the original MAC address of the WAN interface, therefore a new MAC address will result in being issued a different IP address from your ISP.

Yes,it changes mostly after 24 hours or may be 36 hours.for this much of time our ISP has given that particular IP address in lease. After that time it will change automatically.You can change manually also.  You can check the lease timing and all stuff using this open cmd prompt and type  =>  ipconfig /all  see the pic.After this time my pc's IP going to change.

Yes, you can. If you mean your private IP address, you can change that to a static IP address on your local system. Your public IP address can be changed on your router. Of course, it’s likely that nothing will work anymore.

Yes and no.  But most of the IP address are dynamicly assigned.  That means that there an automatic mechanism named dhcp that makes sure the give an IP address to each products that needs one.  So yes. IP address change every x days depend on the settings.  If u setup IP address manually it wont change.

It depends on how your network is set up, and how your ISP assigns IP addresses. Some IP addresses are static (Don’t change), and some assign dynamic IP addresses (They do change). A changing IP address is also a form of security against network attacks or breaches.

IP address stands for ‘internet protocol'. It's something like the address that is assigned to your device. And it differs as you change your location.And it can't be changed automatically.you can change your IP address using a vpn. VPN provides a virtual address to your device.
Yes you can change IP address of any device if you have appropriate access & privileges to that device.

It depends on the network you connected. If you are using a Mobile internet, then you will get an IP address assigned by the Internet Service Provider. If you are connected to a Wi-Fi router then you will get any IP address in the range of 10.0.0.1 - 10.255.255.255, 172.16.0.1–172.31.255.255 and 192.168.0.1 - 192.168.255.255. For example, you are connected to a D-link Wi-fi router has a default IP address of 192.168.0.1. Now let’s take 5 devices like mobile or system connected to that wi-fi, then that devices get Ip addresses like 192.168.0.2, 192.168.0.3 up to 192.168.0.6. Initially, you have 192.168.0.3 then you get disconnected and again connected. Now your IP address will be changed.
